challenges.title: Beginning HTML and CSS Projects with Tests
description: Our front end development projects will give you a chance to apply the front end skills you've learned up to this point.

These projects come with tests that you will need to pass.

Link in the test suite following the instructions in the Introduction to JS Bin.

You can add the test scripts to your project when you are ready to start testing.

You can also comment out or remove the scripts while you are working to remove the testing interface.

The projects will give you guidance on the web page you are to build.

Do NOT spend a lot of time on the design or content of your web page.

The goal of these projects are to get you familiar with writing a complete page of HTML and CSS.

You are working towards being a Front End Developer not a graphics or web designer.

In all future projects you will be given the design for you project.

Focus on the code and how it looks, do NOT focus on how your output looks.

In the test interface you will need to pick the project you are working on in the drop down box.

Click the Run Tests button to run the tests and the Test 10/10 to see the results.

To get the tests to pass you will need to READ the error messages.

Please fully read both the error message (next to the number) and AssertionError (at the top of the highlighted box), they provide the clues for what needs to be fixed.

If you get stuck, please use the methodology:

Research-Ask

challenges.title: ** Commit to not solve other students problems - Beginning HTML
description:
Computer programming requires excellent problem solving skills.

Working through problems with the help of documentation is a daily activity for all programmers.
When students give help it should only be to point out where in the documentation, books or other materials where they can learn about a concept.
Students should never give away a solution to a problem or share code that completes a problem.
If a student is still unable to solve a problem, please, refer them to the tutor.
If you and the other student(s) have finished and passed off the project or challenge feel free to discuss, share techniques and source code.
However, please do not discuss within earshot of other students that have not passed off to that point.
By clicking below you commit to not solve other students problems, share code or give away answers.

challenges.title: Build a Tribute Page
description: Build your project on JS Bin.  Add the "CodeCamp" Test Suite from the libraries to access the Tribute Page tests.
User Story: The page is a single web page that is a tribute to a person or a place.
User Story: The page contains an image of the topic.
User Story: The page contains descriptive text about the topic.
User Story: The page contains an external link that will open another browser window.
You must pass the tests below
Technology Stack: 1. Use only HTML and CSS to complete this project, do NOT use any libraries.
Content: 1. The page contains an element with corresponding id="main", which contains all other elements.
Content: 2. The page contains an element with corresponding id="title", which contains a text that describes the topic of the page.
Content: 3. The page contains a div element with corresponding id="img-div".
Content: 4. Within the "img-div" element, the page contains an img element with a corresponding id="image". ‣
Content: 5. Within the "img-div" element, the page contains an element with a corresponding id="img-caption" that contains textual content describing the image shown in "img-div".
Content: 6. The page contains an element with a corresponding id="tribute-info", which contains textual content describing the subject of the tribute page.
Content: 7. The page contains an a element with a corresponding id="tribute-link", which links to an outside site that contains additional information about the subject of the tribute page.
Layout: 1. The img element should responsively resize, relative to the width of its parent element, without exceeding its original size.
Layout: 2. The img element should be centered within its parent element.
Remember to use the Research-Ask method if you get stuck.

challenges.title: Build a Survey Form
description: Build your project on JS Bin.  Add the "CodeCamp" Test Suite from the libraries to access the Tribute Page tests.
You must pass the tests below
Technology Stack: 1. Use only HTML and CSS to complete this project, do NOT use any libraries.
Content: 1. The page contains a title with id="title" in H1 sized text.
Content: 2. The page contains a short explanation with id="description" in P sized text.
Content: 3. The page contains a form with id="survey-form".
Content: 4. Inside the form element, I am required to enter my name in a field with id="name".
Content: 5. Inside the form element, I am required to enter an email in a field with id="email".
Content: 6. If I enter an email that is not formatted correctly, I will see an HTML5 validation error.
Content: 7. Inside the form, I can enter a number in a field with id="number".
Content: 8. If I enter non-numbers in the number input, I will see an HTML5 validation error.
Content: 9. If I enter numbers outside the range of the number input, I will see an HTML5 validation error.

Content: 10. For the name, email, and number input fields inside the form The page contains corresponding labels that describe the purpose of each field with the following ids: id="name-label", id="email-label", and id="number-label".
Content: 11. For the name, email, and number input fields, The page contains placeholder text that gives me a description or instructions for each field.
Content: 12. Inside the form element, I can select an option from a dropdown that has corresponding id="dropdown".
Content: 13. Inside the form element, I can select a field from one or more groups of radio buttons. Each group should be grouped using the name attribute.
Content: 14. Inside the form element, I can select several fields from a series of checkboxes, each of which must have a value attribute.
Content: 15. Inside the form element, I am presented with a textarea at the end for additional comments.
Content: 16. Inside the form element, I am presented with a button with id="submit" to submit all my inputs.
Remember to use the Research-Ask method if you get stuck.

challenges.title: Build a Product Landing Page
description: Build your project on JS Bin.  Add the "CodeCamp" Test Suite from the libraries to access the Product Landing Page tests.
You must pass the tests below
Technology Stack: 1. Use only HTML and CSS to complete this project, do NOT use any libraries.
Content: 1. My product landing page should have a header element with corresponding id="header".
Content: 2. I can see an image within the #header element with a corresponding id="header-img". A company logo would make a good image here.
Content: 3. Within the header element I can see a nav element with corresponding id="nav-bar".
Content: 4. I can see at least three clickable elements inside the nav element, each with the class "nav-link".
Content: 5. When I click a .nav-link button in the nav element, I am taken to the corresponding section of the landing page.
Content: 6. I can watch an embedded product video with id="video".
Content: 7. My landing page has a form element with a corresponding id="form".
Content: 8. Within the form, there is an input field with id="email" where I can enter an email address.
Content: 9. The #email input field should have placeholder text to let the user know what the field is for.
Content: 10. The #email input field uses HTML5 validation to confirm that the entered text is an email address.
Content: 11. Within the form, there is a submit input with corresponding id="submit".
Content: 12. When I click the #submit element, the email is submitted to a static page (use this mock URL: https://site.com/email-submit) that confirms the email address
Layout: 1. The navbar should always be at the top of the viewport.
Layout: 2. My product landing page should have at least one media query.
Layout: 3. My product landing page should utilize CSS flexbox at least once.
Remember to use the Research-Ask method if you get stuck.

challenges.title: Build a Technical Documentation Page
description: Build your project on JS Bin.  Add the "CodeCamp" Test Suite from the libraries to access the Technical Documentation Page tests.
You must pass the tests below
Technology Stack: 1. Use only HTML and CSS to complete this project, do NOT use any libraries.
Content: 1. I can see a main element with a corresponding id="main-doc", which contains the page main content (technical documentation).
Content: 2. Within the #main-doc ( main ) element, I can see several section elements, each with a class of "main-section". There should be a minimum of 5.
Content: 3. The first element within each .main-section should be a header element which contains text that describes the topic of that section.

Content: 4. Each
element with the class of "main-section" should also have an id that corresponds with the text of each header contained within it. Any spaces should be replaced with underscores (e.g. The section that contains the header "JavaScript and Java" should have a corresponding id="Javascript_and_Java").
Content: 5. The .main-section elements should contain at least 10 p elements total (not each).
Content: 6. The .main-section elements should contain at least 5 code elements total (not each).
Content: 7. The .main-section elements should contain at least 5 li items total (not each).
Content: 8. I can see a nav element with a correspondingv id="navbar".
Content: 9. The navbar element should contain one header element which contains text that describes the topic of the technical documentation.
Content: 10. Additionally, the navbar should contain link (a) elements with the class of "nav-link". There should be one for every element with the class "main-section".
Content: 11. The header element in the navbar must come before any link (a) elements in the navbar.

Content: 12. Each element with the class of "nav-link" should contain text that corresponds to the header text within each section (e.g. if you have a "Hello world" section/header, your navbar should have an element which contains the text "Hello world").

Content: 13. When I click on a navbar element, the page should navigate to the corresponding section of the "main-do" element (e.g. If I click on a "nav-link" element that contains the text "Hello world", the page navigates to a section element that has that id and contains the corresponding header.
Layout: 1. On regular sized devices (laptops, desktops), the element with id="navbar" should be shown on the left side of the screen and should always be visible to the user.
Layout: 2. My Technical Documentation page should use at least one media query.
Remember to use the Research-Ask method if you get stuck.

challenges.title: Build a Personal Portfolio Webpage
description: Build your project on JS Bin.  Add the "CodeCamp" Test Suite from the libraries to access the Personal Portfolio Webpage tests.
You must pass the tests below
Technology Stack: 1. Use only HTML and CSS to complete this project, do NOT use any libraries.
Content: 1. My portfolio should have a Welcome section with an id of "welcome-section".
Content: 2. The welcome section should have an h1 element that contains text.
Content: 3. My portfolio should have a projects section with an id of "projects".
Content: 4. The projects section should contain at least one element with a class of "project-tile" to hold a project.
Content: 5. The projects section should contain at least one link to a project.
Content: 6. My portfolio should have a navbar with an id of "navbar".
Content: 7. The navbar should contain at least one link that I can click on to navigate to different sections of the page.
Content: 8. My portfolio should have a link with an id of "profile-link", which opens my FCC profile in a new tab.
Layout: 1. My portfolio page should use at least one media query.
Layout: 2. The height of the welcome section should be equal to the height of the viewport.
Layout: 3. The navbar should always be at the top of the viewport.
Remember to use the Research-Ask method if you get stuck.
